lessons.title: CSS: The Style
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - CSS = Cascading Style Sheets (makes HTML look good) - Selectors target HTML elements - Cascade: styles can override each other - Specificity determines which style wins --- # CSS: Making It Pretty ## What is CSS? CSS makes HTML **look good**. Without CSS, all websites would look like plain text! ## Basic Syntax ```css selector { property: value; } ``` **Example:** ```css h1 { color: blue; font-size: 32px; } ``` ## Selectors **Element:** ```css p { color: black; } ``` **Class:** ```css .button { background: blue; } ``` ```html
Click me
``` **ID:** ```css #header { height: 100px; } ``` ```html
Header
``` **Multiple selectors:** ```css h1, h2, h3 { font-family: Arial; } ``` **Descendant:** ```css nav a { color: white; } ``` Targets `` inside `
` ## The Box Model Every element is a box: ``` ┌─────────────────────────────┐ │ Margin │ │ ┌───────────────────────┐ │ │ │ Border │ │ │ │ ┌─────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ Padding │ │ │ │ │ │ ┌───────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ Content │ │ │ │ │ │ │ └───────────┘ │ │ │ │ │ └─────────────────┘ │ │ │ └───────────────────────┘ │ └─────────────────────────────┘ ``` ```css .box { width: 200px; padding: 20px; /* Space inside */ border: 2px solid black; margin: 10px; /* Space outside */ } ``` ## Layout: Flexbox **Modern way to layout:** ```css .container { display: flex; justify-content: center; /* Horizontal */ align-items: center; /* Vertical */ gap: 20px; /* Space between items */ } ``` ## Common Properties **Text:** ```css color: blue; font-size: 16px; font-weight: bold; text-align: center; ``` **Background:** ```css background-color: #f0f0f0; background-image: url('photo.jpg'); ``` **Sizing:** ```css width: 100%; height: 200px; max-width: 800px; ``` **Spacing:** ```css margin: 10px; /* All sides */ margin: 10px 20px; /* Top/bottom, left/right */ padding: 10px 20px 30px 40px; /* Top, right, bottom, left */ ``` ## Specificity (What Wins?) When multiple styles conflict: 1. **Inline styles** (highest) 2. **IDs** (#header) 3. **Classes** (.button) 4. **Elements** (p, div) ```css p { color: black; } /* 1 point */ .text { color: blue; } /* 10 points */ #title { color: red; } /* 100 points */ ``` `#title` wins! ## The Cascade Styles cascade down: ```css body { font-family: Arial; /* All children inherit this */ } ``` Later styles override earlier ones: ```css p { color: blue; } p { color: red; } /* This wins */ ```

lessons.title: Tailwind: Utility-First CSS
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - Tailwind = utility-first CSS framework - Uses classes like `flex`, `p-4`, `bg-blue-500` - No need to write custom CSS - Faster development but more HTML classes --- # Tailwind: A Different Approach ## What is Tailwind? Tailwind is a **utility-first** CSS framework. Instead of writing CSS, you use pre-made classes. ## Traditional CSS vs Tailwind **Traditional CSS:** ```html ``` ```css .btn-primary { background-color: blue; color: white; padding: 12px 24px; border-radius: 4px; } ``` **Tailwind:** ```html ``` No CSS file needed! ## Common Tailwind Classes **Spacing:** ```html

questions.question: Which is the most semantic way to mark up a navigation menu?
questions.explanation: <nav> is the semantic HTML5 element specifically for navigation.

questions.question: Which should you use for the main content of a page?
questions.explanation: <main> is the semantic element for the primary content of a page.

questions.question: What's wrong with:
questions.explanation: Images should always have an alt attribute for accessibility.

questions.question: Which selector has the HIGHEST specificity?
questions.explanation: ID selectors (#) have higher specificity than classes (.) or elements.
Class selector (.important) has higher specificity than element selector (p).

questions.question: What does 'box-sizing: border-box' do?
questions.explanation: border-box makes width/height include padding and border, making sizing more predictable.

exercises.title: Tailwind vs Traditional CSS
exercises.description: Compare Tailwind and traditional CSS approaches.

questions.question: What does 'p-4' mean in Tailwind?
questions.explanation: p-4 means padding: 1rem (16px). Tailwind's spacing scale: 1 = 0.25rem, 4 = 1rem.

questions.question: Main benefit of Tailwind?
options: No need to write custom CSS
questions.explanation: Tailwind provides utility classes so you rarely need to write custom CSS.

questions.question: What does 'md:text-lg' mean?
questions.explanation: md: is a responsive prefix - applies text-lg only on medium screens and up.

questions.question: What's the main benefit of Sass variables?
questions.explanation: Variables let you define values once and reuse them, making updates easier.

questions.question: What does @mixin do?
questions.explanation: Mixins are reusable blocks of styles that you can @include in other selectors.

questions.question: Do browsers understand .scss files?
options: No, must be compiled to CSS
questions.explanation: SCSS must be compiled to regular CSS before browsers can use it.

questions.question: Main advantage of CSS-in-JS?
questions.explanation: CSS-in-JS scopes styles to components, preventing global naming conflicts.

questions.question: Can you use JavaScript variables in CSS-in-JS?
questions.explanation: CSS-in-JS allows dynamic styles using JavaScript variables and props.

questions.question: Main drawback of CSS-in-JS?
questions.explanation: Some CSS-in-JS libraries compute styles at runtime, adding overhead.
